reviewText: This film will not likely win the hearts and minds of the average film-goer. But it ranks right up there with "Platoon" and "Go Tell the Spartans" as among the very best of the Vietnam war films.It pulls few punches in its depiction of that war's brutality. It is totally stripped  of all sentimentality. Importantly, it sympathetically portrays both Vietcong and American humanity, feelings and attitudes at the infantry level.A plus to this film is R. Lee Ermey's (also see "Full Metal Jacket" and "The Boys in Company C.") portrail of Marine Sgt Major Bill Haffner who, at the beginning of the film, is in command of a small recon squad. Later, upon "relieving" an inept dope-smoking Army captain of command, is ultimately in charge of shaping up an entire company of near misfit GI's at Firebase Gloria. He job is to fortify the base and defend it from an impending Vietcong attack. The ensuing battle sequences are as harrowingly realistic as any you'll see anywhere. Real life ex-marine Ermey is completely convincing, funny and entertaining even though, at times, he appears slightly uncomfortable in the lead role.Some viewers may take exception to Sgt Haffner's unprovoked beratement of Nurse Capt. Flanagan. Under the circumstances, one would think her and her nurses presence would be greatly appreciated. It's my only gripe with the film.Australian director, Brian Trenchard-Smith has stuck his neck out and made a remarkable, sleeper of a war film. Any war film fan who hasn't seen this film is in for a pleasant (or unpleasant, depending on your viewpoint) surprise. Others should view it for a reality check. At the current price, it is an unbelievable bargain. Don't miss it!
summary: Brutal, in your face depiction of a true incident in 'Nam

reviewText: This film, "The Siege of Firebase Gloria," is more than a sleeper. It is a keeper. I never heard of it before. Do I want to re-visit the morass of Vietnam as told by draft dodgers with a dubbed narration of a stoned hippie? No. The film crew were surely the tortoise who out-foxed the hare. Given B grade studio support and logistics, this crew exceeds all expectations with all the similarities to other Vietnam films fading away the deeper the squad goes. The director Brian Trenchard-Smith with the taut script of William Nagle and Tony Johnston bring the pyrotechnics of any Sam Fuller war film to this mission, take you through familiar landscape (a la "Pork Chop Hill", "We Were Soldiers") with freshly unique chops. With budgetary and logistic restraints, they tell the story from both sides with no confusion. The film has an impact on you of a .223 round from close quarters. And who better to lead you more capably than R. Lee Ermey, who's salty dialogue makes you wince from start to finish, yet keeps you on your toes with his coaxing confidence? When he encounters incompetence, endangering the firebase in the guise of "rank" privileges(why don't we have this in our Washington leaders?)he shockingly removes the impediment to professional soldiering. This is a B movie with a larger bite than the bogus "Platoon," 10 ways to sundown, by golly-gee Audie Murphy. I think this crew would follow R. Lee Ermey to hell and beyond. So would I.

reviewText: Hoping no doubt to cash in on R. Lee Ermey's amazing performance as Gunnery Sgt. Hartman in Full Metal Jacket, the script for The Siege of Firebase Gloria was pumped out to give Ermey yet another movie in which he could shine as a hardcore Marine.  Oorah!A weary Sgt. Major Hafner (Ermey) and his combat-hardened right-hand man, Di Nardo (Wings Hauser), walk out of the jungles of Vietnam into a hellhole known as Firebase Gloria.  Replete with danger and cliché, FBG must be protected at all costs against Viet Cong forces that outnumber his newly inherited collection of complacent men 5-to-1.  Finding the commanding officer in a hash-fueled haze, Hafner assumes command and begins whipping the rag-tag collection into shape with lines like, "There is no doubt in my military mind that we are in a deep s*#@ situation, people!"  Hoping to withstand the inevitable VC barrage, Hafner realizes during a Tet Offensive onslaught that best efforts may not be enough, and advises his men: "A little religious communication might not be a bad idea at this state in the game."  Classic Ermey lines, perfect delivery.The popularity of Vietnam movies during the late 80s was high, and this is one that easily falls in the upper half.  It attacks on the personal level with vicious battles and plenty of death, but it fails to embrace some of the minor authenticity details.  The battles themselves look realistic, and have been corroborated by enough Vietnam Vets to convince me, but some of the handling of weapons by minor characters is downright laughable.  At one point there is a door-gunner in the Air Cav who is firing an M-60 with the butt of the weapon above his head.  Other obvious problems exist - like a weakling, female captain serving as a doctor with no weapon or leadership knowledge - but they don't detract enough from a good old fashioned war movie.  Some say the best Vietnam movie ever made.  And don't even get me started on Gary Hershberger's dead on arrival portrayal of an oddball helicopter pilot.The highlight of the movie is R. Lee Ermey and a few of his classically delivered lines.  The low budget adds a bit of grittiness to the characters and the situation.  War isn't pretty, and neither is this movie, but the brutality of the situation is utterly convincing.  There is an underlying subplot involving the politics behind Hanoi's Tet Offensive decisions, but for the majority of the film it's bullets and explosions ripping through Charlie's guts, and bayonets carving Victor Charlie's organs.  Highly recommended for military and war movie fans.Jason Elin
summary: A criminally unknown R. Lee Ermey Vietnam flick

reviewText: Above all else a movie must present a well crafted story. While "The Siege of Firebase Gloria" is fictional as is "Go Tell the Spartans" both pictures were very well crafted and well acted throughout. Both present a different time frame in the same war. A war where an American lead military invention into a communist insurgency was conducted to different sets of rules. Fire Base Gloria showed to me that that the American tactics fell into the same errors maded by the French - fixed positions on the one hand with localised incursions into other areas occupied by the Viet Cong or the North Vietnamese.( "Hamburger Hill" "We Were Soldiers"). At all times the countryside was never pacified - only the areas actually occupied could be said to have been partially pacified.While movies like "Platoon" attempted to make political and moral statements about the Vietnam War, it was and is evident that notwithstanding the bravery of the average American soldier, the tactics employed by the upper level of the American military revealed a false premise in that they never really came to grips with the nature of their enemy, whereby  the make up of their enemy were peasants who plowed the rice paddies by day and picked up a AK 47 at night. An enemy who did not hesitate to hide over geographical borders how and when it suited them. What Fire Base Gloria typifies that the thinking of American military command were geared up to fight a conventional ground war with an enemy that did not play to their rules.Ho knew that if he sent enough Americans and their allies back home in body bags then it would be the American public who would lose their hearts and minds in the war and any determination to continue the war, but this attitude may not have been necessarily the attitude of the American soldiers themselves. This comes through in the conclusion of Fire Base Gloria.Movies like "Go Tell the Spartans" and "The Siege of Fire Base Gloria"  tell a graphic truth, and that truth is that an army geared to fight a European war with General Patton like tactics will never completely defeat a local "peasant" insurgency war where the enemy can simply melt away into the general population - Afghanistan typifies this.It always seems strange to me the that American Military command did not seem to learn from the earlier British experience in Malaya, a campaign that actually defeated the communist insurgents.I highly recommend "The siege of Fire Base Gloria" as a depiction of the Vietnam War - a well crafted movie.

reviewText: Chillingly accurate. As others have said, you don't need a big budget and star names to make it real. This rests in my collection next to the Aussie movie The Odd Angry Shot, which again goes for realism, not frills and sensationalism.For me, the scene that captures the nature of the Enemy and the barbarity of gloves-off, no-quarter warfare was the one in which a VC shoots up the medical bunker, with a total disregard for the Geneva Convention. After deliberately killing personnel and destroying bottles of plasma, blood and other essential supplies, he is finally killed my a female doctor with an M-16. God bless her.Compassionate representations or not, this was a ruthless Enemy, who even booby-trapped live babies in order to kill American soldiers.Firebase Gloria vividly captures the frantic scrabble to stave off annihilation by a psychotic VC assault force, who literally attacked in Korea-style human waves. Where indeed was Tac Air? The Enemy should have been swimming in napalm.One of the most gratifying moments in this video comes at the end, when the text reveals that the Enemy (mainly VC) lost as many men during Tet as the US lost during the entire Vietnam War. Militarily, Tet was a total failure. Yet it had tremendous political significance, and greatly aided the Communists back in the USA in accelerating their hijack of the Peace Movement.Don't get me wrong, I think the War was a mistake, primarily because it was entered into with no concept of a Win Scenario in mind. As the French found, you simply cannot fight a holding operation against an enemy like the NVA and VC. You either leave 'em to it, or you wipe them out.

reviewText: The Siege of Firebase Gloria is somewhat thin on plot but more than makes up for it in credible nonstop action. There are some technical flaws, but these are easy to overlook for the movie's entertainment value.The plot is loosely based on the (actual) Battle of Khe Sahn, and is quickly summarized: a battalion of regular Vietcong are amassing for an assault on Firebase Gloria. A USMC LRRP patrol (actually: no such thing existed; LRRPs were US Army) led by Sgt. Major Hafner is helicoptered to the firebase where he "relieves of command" the incompetent c.o. Captain Williams, and proceeds to fortify the base against the VC onslaught he realizes is about to be launched. He has no hope of reinforcement, since this happens when the rest of the US forces in Vietnam are being assaulted by the Tet Offensive.The Vietcong commander has problems of his own. He must secure victory without suffering excessive loss of troops, since this would allow the regular forces of North Vietnam to take away control of the war in the South.  Unlike all the other 'Nam flicks, F.G. portrays the enemy as something other than a nameless, amorphous collection of black-pajama Kalishnikov-wielders.There are many, though minor, technical errors throughout the film. It's not SOP for a USMC NCO to take command of an Army installation from an Army officer. There were never any nurses working on frontline fighting positions. None of the men on the base wear any rank insignia; Hafner and DiNardo are wearing tigerstripe camo uniforms. Another oddity is the green towel that Hafner is constantly wearing around his neck (definitely not standard issue). Sometimes others of the troops are also seen wearing the green towel. Go figure.Nevertheless, what's important is the combat, and this is portrayed rather well. The Gloria troops are obviously well-equipped with M79 40 mm grenade launchers, M60 portable machine guns, M18 Claymore mines, and some (including DiNardo) with the venerable M-14 chambered for 7.62 x 59 mm NATO. Contrary to one of the one-star reviewers here, there actually WERE a few still in use in Vietnam. The VC troops all seem to have the ubiquitous AK-47. The US Army Aircav is also well represented with UH-1 Hueys.Be forewarned that the film is filled with the usual foul-mouthed language used by soldiers in combat. There are quite a few wickedly humorous lines, though few repeatable at your next church social.All in all, your typical thin-on-plot shoot-em-up war flick, though outstandingly well done. Five stars.
summary: most exciting Vietnam flick of them all, if flawed
